conclusion: Four identical wooden blocks are on a smooth horizontal surface, blocks B and C are connected by a light spring, a horizontal pulling force F is applied to block B, all blocks accelerate together with the same acceleration.
Force F = ma is applied on block B, and there's also a force f = ma acting on block D.
Each block has mass m, all blocks have the same acceleration a, the surface is smooth except for the static friction between blocks.
Block B has applied force F pulling to the right and spring force pulling to the left.
Block A must have static friction force from B pushing A forward to accelerate with the same acceleration a.
Block C is pulled to the right by the spring connected to B and must also push block D with static friction.
Force f = ma acting on block D to the left represents the static friction force between block D and the external environment.
The total force on the system must equal the total mass times acceleration: F = (4m)a.
If F = ma is the total external force and the total system has mass 4m, then the system acceleration would be a = F/(4m) = a/4.
The static friction force on block D equals ma in magnitude, directed to the left, counteracting its tendency to move with the system.
The magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D during the acceleration process is ma.
